PARAGRAPH.STRING: (It.: Dente del Gigante) (4,013 m) is a mountain in the Mont Blanc massif in France and Italy.

has two distinct summits, eighty-eight feet apart and separated by a small col (an 'extremely awkward notch' according to W. W. Graham): *Pointe Graham (4,013 m), first ascent by W. W. Graham with guides Auguste Cupelin and Alphonse Payot on 20 August 1882.*Pointe Sella (4,009 m), first ascent by Jean Joseph Maquignaz with son Baptiste Maquignaz and nephew, Daniel Maquignaz on 28 July 1882. The same party climbed Pointe Sella a second time on the following day with clients Alessandro Sella, Alfonso Sella, Corradino Sella and Gaudenzio Sella. Graham noted on his first ascent that one of the Maquignazes had carved the letter 'M' on a rock step just below the summit of Pointe Sella.
had remained unclimbed during the so-called Golden age of alpinism, and
was a much-coveted peak in the 1870s, repelling many parties who attempted

mostly from the Rochefort ridge. In 1880 the strong team of Albert F. Mummery and Alex­ander Burgener tried to force a passage via the south-west face but were repelled by a band of slabs, causing Mummery to exclaim 'Absolutely inaccessible by fair means!'
:*Rifugio Torino (3,372 m, CAI, staffed mid May–end September) *Torino hut (3,332 m, CAI, all year)*Pointe Hellbronner (3,462 m, téléphérique station which can be used as a base)
